questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to a cardiologist for evaluation of a new heart murmur discovered at a routine health screening evaluation. The physician reads the report from this evaluation, which states that the patient was found to have a “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur.” Auscultation at which of the following anatomic locations is most appropriate for reproducing this patient’s characteristic murmur?
questions.solution:
The characteristic crescendo-decresendo systolic ejection murmur described in the question stem refers to aortic stenosis, which is best appreciated over the second intercostal space along the right sternum. Several anatomic areas of the chest wall serve as landmarks for auscultation of different valves of the heart:  

  •  Aortic area: Right second intercostal space, parasternal. Aortic valve murmurs are heard best here, including aortic stenosis (systolic) and aortic regurgitation (diastolic).  
  • Pulmonic area: Left second intercostal space, parasternal. Pulmonic murmurs heard best here, like the systolic ejection murmur of pulmonic stenosis. Physiologic flow murmurs are also best heard here.
  • Tricuspid area: Left fourth intercostal space, parasternal. Diastolic murmurs associated with tricuspid stenosis or atrial septal defects can be heard here, as well as holosystolic murmurs from tricuspid regurgitation and ventricular septal defects. 
  • Mitral area: Left fifth intercostal space, mid-clavicular. One can hear the systolic murmurs from mitral regurgitation or mitral valve prolapse here, in addition to the diastolic mitral stenosis murmur.

Option Analysis

✅ A. :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ B. :
Incorrect: Choice B corresponds to the pulmonic area. This patient’s classic “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur” is most likely from aortic stenosis, which is best heard over the aortic area (area A).
❌ C. :
Incorrect: Choice C corresponds to the tricuspid area.This patient’s classic “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur” is most likely from aortic stenosis, which is best heard over the aortic area (area A).
❌ D. :
Incorrect: Choice D corresponds to the mitral area. This patient’s classic “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur” is most likely from aortic stenosis, which is best heard over the aortic area (area A).
❌ E. :
Incorrect: Choice E does not correspond to a defined auscultatory location. This patient’s classic “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur” is most likely from aortic stenosis, which is best heard over the aortic area (area A).

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to his primary care physician’s office accompanied by his partner following an episode of syncope two days ago. The patient was working in his garden when he suddenly felt light headed and lost consciousness for one minute. His partner, who witnessed the incident, states that he did not jerk uncontrollably or hit his head. The patient endorses worsening shortness of breath and occasional chest pain during his usual morning walk for the past month. Medical history includes benign prostatic hyperplasia, which is managed with finasteride. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 138/87 mmHg. On physical examination, the lungs are clear to auscultation. Neurologic examination is within normal limits. ECG demonstrates voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy. Cardiac auscultation will most likely reveal a murmur in which of the areas marked on the diagram below?

choices.text: Area 2: Ejection murmur accompanied by a fixed split-second heart sound (S2)
Area 5: Opening snap followed by diastolic murmur

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of aortic stenosis (AS) including exertional dyspnea, chest pain, and syncope. On physical examination, AS is heard as a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur over the right 2nd intercostal space.

AS is the most common cause of left ventricular outflow obstruction and is commonly associated with age-related calcifications in patients over the age of sixty, though it can manifest in younger patients due to bicuspid aortic valve or rheumatic heart disease. Common clinical findings include exertional dyspnea, decreased exercise tolerance, dizziness, syncope, exertional angina, and arrhythmias. During exertion, left ventricular dysfunction ensues as the heart pumps against a stenotic valve--thus limiting ejection fraction and blood flow to both peripheral tissues and coronary arteries. Additional physical exam findings include an S2, ejection click, or weak carotid pulse with a delayed peak (“Pulsus parvus et tardus”). An early-peaking murmur typically correlates with mild to moderate AS, whereas a late-peaking murmur often indicates severe AS.



Option Analysis

✅ Area 1: Crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Area 2: Ejection murmur accompanied by a fixed split-second heart sound (S2):
Incorrect: Ejection murmur accompanied by a fixed split-second heart sound (S2) over the left 2nd intercostal space (pulmonic area) can be auscultated with atrial septal defects. Patients with small ASDs are usually asymptomatic.
❌ Area 3: Systolic ejection murmur:
Incorrect: A systolic ejection murmur over the 3rd right intercostal space is associated with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). Patients with HOCM are usually young and present with dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, atypical or anginal chest pain, syncope, palpitations, and sudden cardiac death.
❌ Area 4: Holosystolic murmur:
Incorrect: A holosystolic murmur can be heard over the 4th left intercostal space (tricuspid area) in patients with tricuspid regurgitation and ventricular septal defects. Tricuspid regurgitation often presents with signs of right-sided heart failure (HF), including hepatic congestion, ascites, and peripheral edema. Mild VSDs may be asymptomatic, while large VSDs may induce heart failure.
❌ Area 5: Opening snap followed by diastolic murmur:
Incorrect: An opening snap followed by a rumbling and mid-to-late diastolic murmur best heard at the 5th left midclavicular intercostal space (mitral area) is indicative of mitral stenosis (MS). Clinical features of MS include dyspnea, chest pain, atrial fibrillation, pulmonary hypertension, and hoarseness secondary to left atrial enlargement.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with Marfan syndrome presents with exertional dyspnea and pounding headaches for several months. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac auscultation reveals the murmur demonstrated below over the right sternal border. Palpation of the radial arteries shows a rapidly rising and falling arterial pulse. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of Marfan syndrome presents with exertional dyspnea and pounding headaches and an exam demonstrating a diastolic murmur and "water hammer" pulses; this combinantion is suggestive of aortic regurgitation secondary to aortic root dilation.

Aortic regurgitation (AR) refers to incomplete closure of the aortic valve leaflets during diastole, resulting in backflow of blood into the left ventricle. With this backflow of blood, the left ventricular end-diastolic volume increases, and the heart compensates for this higher pressure via eccentric hypertrophy in order to maintain ejection fraction.

Regurgitation during diastole often manifests as a rapid drop in diastolic blood pressure, and an increase in pulse pressure (systolic pressure minus diastolic pressure). This wide pulse pressure is responsible for many of the phenomena observed in aortic regurgitation, including “water hammer” pulse, pounding headaches, and head bobbing (de Musset sign). Aortic regurgitation is characterized by a diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard over the 3rd intercostal space (‘Erb point’) in the case regurgitation from valvular disease. In the setting of aortic root disease, the murmur is best heard over the right sternal border and apex.



Option Analysis

❌ Patent ductus arteriosus:
Incorrect:  A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) occurs when the ductus arteriosus fails to involute after birth, resulting in a left to right shunt. Infants may present with signs of heart failure, failure to thrive, poor feeding, and respiratory distress; adults may have features of Eisenmenger syndrome, such as cyanosis and clubbing. A PDA is characterized as a “machine-like murmur” best heard over the left infraclavicular area.
❌ Coarctation of the aorta:
Incorrect: Coarctation of the aorta refers to the narrowing of the descending aorta, typically at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, distal to the left subclavian artery. A systolic murmur can sometimes be heard at the left paravertebral interscapular area, and the condition is often associated with conditions such as bicuspid aortic valve. Signs and symptoms include hypertension in upper extremities and weak and delayed pulses in lower extremities.
❌ Aortic stenosis:
 Incorrect:The murmur of aortic stenosis (AS) is characterized as a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur over the right 2nd intercostal space with radiation to the carotids. AS is the most common cause of left ventricular outflow obstruction, and the condition is commonly associated with age-related calcification of the aortic valve. Clinical findings of AS inclue exertional dyspnea, decreased exercise tolerance, dizziness, and syncope. This patient presents with signs of acute right heart failure and deep vein thrombosis, suggesting tricuspid regurgitation.
✅ Aortic regurgitation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mitral stenosis:
Incorrect: Mitral stenosis (MS) is heard as an opening snap followed by a rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur that is best heard at the 5th left midclavicular intercostal space (mitral area). Clinical features of MS include dyspnea, chest pain, hemoptysis, atrial fibrillation, pulmonary hypertension, and hoarseness secondary to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve from left atrial enlargement.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset palpitations, dyspnea, and dizziness. His medical history includes anxiety and atopic dermatitis, managed with fluoxetine and topical corticosteroids, respectively. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 135/86 mmHg. Examination of the chest demonstrates pectus excavatum. Cardiac auscultation reveals a midsystolic click followed by a late-systolic crescendo murmur over the cardiac apex. ECG demonstrates normal sinus rhythm with occasional premature ventricular contractions and early repolarization abnormalities. The patient is provided with lorazepam with improvement in his clinical condition. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with palpitations, anxiety, and dizziness. Cardiac auscultation reveals a midsystolic click followed by later systolic crescendo murmur, and the electrocardiogram demonstrates non-specific repolarization abnormalities and premature ventricular contractions. Together, these findings are most consistent with underlying mitral valve prolapse (MVP).

Mitral valve prolapse is caused by myxomatous valve degeneration, wherein glycosaminoglycans inappropriately deposit in and around cardiac valves causing mechanical dysfunction. Prolapse occurs when valve leaflets shift into the left atrium, and it may be primary (idiopathic or familial) or secondary to connective tissue disease(s) (e.g., Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan syndrome -- as suggested by this patient’s pectus excavatum).

Overall, mitral valve prolapse is the most common cause of mitral regurgitation. During auscultation, the midsystolic click occurs secondary to abrupt tensing of the chordae tendineae during systole. Patients are often asymptomatic, but they may present with dyspnea, palpitations, exercise intolerance, and dizziness. No electrocardiographic findings are a reliable indicator of MVP; however, ECGs commonly demonstrate repolarization abnormalities. Formal diagnosis is made via echocardiography, and repair is indicated when MVP results in severe symptomatic mitral regurgitation.

Option Analysis

❌ Aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: Aortic stenosis (AS) is heard as a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur over the right 2nd intercostal space with radiation to the carotids. AS is the most common cause of left ventricular outflow obstruction. It commonly presents with age-related calcifications in patients over the age of 60, though it can also present in younger patients with underlying bicuspid aortic valve or rheumatic heart disease. Common clinical findings include exertional dyspnea, decreased exercise tolerance, dizziness, syncope, exertional angina, and arrhythmias.
❌ Ventricular septal defect:
Incorrect: A ventricular septal defect results in a holosystolic murmur over the 4th left intercostal space (tricuspid area). A mild VSD may be asymptomatic, while a large VSD may induce heart failure.
✅ Mitral valve prolapse:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Coarctation of the aorta:
Incorrect: Coarctation of the aorta refers to the narrowing of the descending aorta, typically at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, distal to the left subclavian artery. Occasionally, a systolic murmur can be appreciated at the left paravertebral interscapular space. Clinical findings include hypertension in the upper extremities and weak, delayed pulses in the lower extremities.
❌ Mitral stenosis:
Incorrect: Mitral stenosis (MS) is characterized by an opening snap followed by a rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur best heard at the 5th left midclavicular intercostal space (mitral area). Patients with MS present with dyspnea, chest pain, atrial fibrillation, pulmonary hypertension, and hoarseness secondary to left atrial enlargement.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset palpitations and lightheadedness. His symptoms began one hour ago while working in his garden. He reports similar episodes over the past several months that self-resolved. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min irregularly irregular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, a rumbling mid-diastolic murmur is heard over the cardiac apex when the patient lies in the left lateral decubitus position. Further history will most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Family history of sudden cardiac death

questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent palpitations, an irregularly irregular rhythm, and a rumbling mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex. These findings suggest atrial fibrillation secondary to mitral stenosis. The most common cause of mitral stenosis is rheumatic heart disease, which often presents with recurrent joint pain during childhood.

Mitral stenosis (MS) refers to a stenotic or mitral valve that impedes blood flow into the left ventricle during diastole. In the case of rheumatic heart disease, pathogenesis involves antibody production and a subsequent T cell response against myosin, which shares similar epitopes with the M protein virulence factor of the bacteria (type II hypersensitivity). This immune response results in recurrent inflammation and fibrinous repair of the mitral valve, leaflet thickening, and commissural fusion. Of note, 50-70% of patients with MS report a history of rheumatic fever.

Clinical features of MS include dyspnea, chest pain, atrial fibrillation, pulmonary hypertension, and hoarseness secondary to left atrial enlargement. Atrial fibrillation often occurs in patients with MS due prolonged elevation of left atrial pressure, left atrial enlargement, and cardiac remodeling, all of which result in cardiac conduction disturbance. 

Option Analysis

❌ Family history of sudden cardiac death:
Incorrect: Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is an autosomal dominant cardiac disorder that results in left-ventricular outflow obstruction. Patients with HOCM are typically young and present with dyspnea on exertion, atypical or anginal chest pain, exertional syncope, palpitations, and sudden cardiac death. Cardiac auscultation reveals a systolic ejection murmur over the 3rd right intercostal space.
✅ Recurrent juvenile arthropathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypercoagulable state :
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolism may result in pulmonary hypertension, right heart failure, and subsequent tricuspid regurgitation. The characteristics of this patient’s murmur favor another diagnosis.
❌ Low T4 level:
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism is a potential reversible cause of atrial fibrillation; however, hyperthyroidism would present with high T4 hormone levels.
❌ Myxomatous valve degeneration:
Incorrect: Mitral valve prolapse is caused by myxomatous valve degeneration due to glycosaminoglycan deposition in and around the cardiac valves. It may be primary (idiopathic or familial) or secondary to connective tissue disease (e.g. Marfan or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). During auscultation, a midsystolic click is appreciated due to abrupt tensing of the chordae tendineae. Patients are often asymptomatic or present with nonspecific symptoms including dyspnea, palpitations, exercise intolerance, or dizziness.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of fatigue and exertional dyspnea for six months. He discloses occasional palpitations and difficulty sleeping in a supine position due to shortness of breath. His medical history includes hypertension and myocardial infarction at age 58. Medications include lisinopril, aspirin, and clopidogrel. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for thirty years. He drinks alcohol socially and does not use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 139/87 mmHg. The patient undergoes cardiac catheterization, with hemodynamic results demonstrated on the diagram below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s cardiac catheterization hemodynamic findings are consistent with mitral regurgitation, which refers to the backflow of blood into the left atrium during ventricular systole. When the ventricles contract, some blood flows back into the left atrium, resulting in a higher left atrial pressure and a characteristic tall v-wave. Secondarily, increased pressure in the left atrium increases hydrostatic pressure in the lung capillaries, causing pulmonary edema. Additional clinical findings include paroxysmal or persistent atrial fibrillation. If left untreated, eccentric hypertrophy may occur due to cardiac remodeling.

Mitral regurgitation is most commonly due to mitral valve prolapse or secondary to causes such as ischemia, left ventricular dilation (functional MR), infective endocarditis, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. On physical examination, a holosystolic murmur is usually heard over the cardiac apex. Surgical repair is required in severe disease.  



Option Analysis

❌ Mitral stenosis:
Incorrect: A stenotic mitral valve results in a higher pressure gradient between the left atrium and left ventricle--especially during early diastole, when the blood flow across the valve peaks. The increased pressure in left atrium pressure can lead to pulmonary edema secondary to increased pulmonary capillary hydrostatic pressure.


✅ Mitral regurgitation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: A stenotic aortic valve leads to a higher pressure gradient between the left ventricle and the aortic pressure. Normally, a small pressure gradient is required to eject blood through the aortic valve, and the pressure gradient increases substantially with aortic stenosis (marked by the grey area below). Clinical manifestations include exertional dyspnea, dizziness, syncope, and angina.


❌ Aortic regurgitation:
Incorrect: Aortic regurgitation occurs secondary to backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole and results in a lower diastolic pressure and wide pulse pressures (e.g., 120/40 instead of 120/80). Clinically, this condition manifests as bounding pulses, diastolic heart murmur, and (rarely) head bobbing.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a syncopal episode during football practice. The patient was running towards the end-zone when he suddenly collapsed. Current temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/85 mmHg. ECG demonstrates downsloping ST segment and T wave inversions in leads I, aVL, V4-V6, as well as prominent Q waves in leads II, III, and aVF. On physical examination, a systolic murmur is appreciated over the lower left sternal border. Which of the following maneuvers will increase the intensity of this murmur?
questions.solution:
This young patient presents with exertional syncope and characteristic ECG findings of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM), including dagger q-waves in the inferior leads. In this condition, maneuvers that increase afterload or preload will both increase left ventricular volume--which will widen the left ventricular outflow tract and decrease the intensity of this murmur.

Several maneuvers may assist in the diagnosis of common cardiac murmurs. Maneuvers that increase preload include rapid squatting or passive straight leg raise; these maneuvers will increase the intensity of the mitral regurgitation and aortic regurgitation murmurs, while decreasing the intensity of the murmur associated with HOCM. The valsalva maneuver will decrease preload, thus increasing the murmur associated with HOCM. Sustained handgrip will increase afterload, thus increasing the intensity of the mitral regurgitation and aortic regurgitation murmurs, while decreasing the murmur associated with HOCM. A summary of the effects these maneuvers have on various murmurs is demonstrated in the chart below.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Rapid standing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sustained hand grip :
Incorrect: Sustained hand grip increases afterload. In a patient with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, increased afterload elevates left ventricular volume and alleviates the ventricular outlet obstruction--thus decreasing the intensity of the murmur.
❌ Rapid squatting:
Incorrect: Rapid squatting increases venous return, increases afterload, and increases preload. In a patient with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, increased afterload and preload elevates left ventricular volume and alleviates the ventricular outlet obstruction--thus decreasing the intensity of the murmur.
❌ Passive straight leg raise:
Incorrect: Passive straight leg raise increases the preload. In a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, an increase in preload increases the left ventricular volume, reducing outlet obstruction and murmur intensity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to his primary care physician complaining of occasional palpitations and dizziness for three months. He discloses associated exertional dyspnea. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/86 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient’s height is 200 cm (6’5’’) and BMI is 17.5 kg/m2. An increased arm span to height ratio is noted. Examination of the back demonstrates scoliosis. Cardiac auscultation reveals a mid systolic murmur over the left 5th intercostal space midclavicular line. Which of the following will decrease the intensity and duration of the murmur?

choices.text: Abrupt standing from a seated position

questions.solution:
This patient with increased arm span to height ratio, scoliosis and low BMI likely has Marfan syndrome, which is associated with mitral valve prolapse (MVP). MVP may be primary (idiopathic or familial) or secondary to connective tissue disease (e.g. Marfan or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). Patients are often asymptomatic or present with specific symptoms including dyspnea, palpitations, exercise intolerance, or dizziness.

The MVP murmur is characterized by a mid systolic click followed by a systolic murmur best heard over the cardiac apex. The click is thought to occur secondary to abrupt snapping of the chordae tendineae during systole. Maneuvers that decrease the preload (e.g., valsalva, abrupt standing) will decrease ventricular wall tension and tension of the chordae tendineae--causing the prolapse to occur sooner and with greater intensity and duration. Maneuvers that increase the preload (e.g., squatting, passive leg raise) will increase ventricular wall and chordae tendineae tension, decreasing the intensity and duration of the murmur.







Option Analysis

❌ Abrupt standing from a seated position:
Incorrect: This patient likely has Marfan syndrome, which is associated with mitral valve prolapse. Abrupt standing from a seated position will reduce preload, lead to an earlier mid systolic click and a longer murmur.
❌ Valsalva maneuver :
Incorrect: This patient likely has Marfan syndrome, which is associated with mitral valve prolapse. Valsalva maneuver compresses the inferior vena cava and reduces the preload. As a result, the chordae tendineae are not tensed, and the valve leaflets are not properly positioned, leading to an earlier mid-systolic click and a longer murmur.
✅ Passive leg raise:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nitroglycerin administration:
Incorrect: Nitroglycerin, which is primarily a venodilator, will decrease preload, thus increasing the intensity and duration of the murmur.
❌ Placement in reverse Trendelenburg position:
Incorrect: Placement in reverse Trendelenburg position will have the same effect as abrupt standing from a seated position, as both will reduce preload and increase the intensity and duration of the murmur.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of new onset shortness of breath and fatigue. She reports shortness of breath while lying flat, and she occasionally wakes up at night gasping for air. She also endorses an occasional productive cough with a “brown” tinge. Her medical history includes a “cardiac condition” in her youth that was treated with antibiotics. She immigrated to the United States from India at age 10. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg. ECG is obtained and demonstrated below. Cardiac auscultation will most likely demonstrate which of the following findings?

choices.text: Systolic murmur over the left paravertebral interscapular area
Continuous murmur at the left infraclavicular area
Systolic ejection murmur over the 3rd right intercostal space
Diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex
Holosystolic murmur over the left sternal border

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea and rust colored sputum. Her previous history is suspicious for rheumatic heart disease, and the ECG reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm with absent P waves, consistent with atrial fibrillation. Together, this constellation of findings suggests underlying mitral stenosis (MS).

The murmur of mitral stenosis is characterized by an opening snap and a mid-diastolic murmur best appreciated over the cardiac apex. Accentuation of the murmur is heard with the patient in a left lateral decubitus position. Patients with MS may present with dyspnea, chest pain, rust colored sputum, atrial fibrillation, pulmonary hypertension, and hoarseness secondary to left atrial enlargement.    

Option Analysis

❌ Systolic murmur over the left paravertebral interscapular area:
Incorrect: A systolic murmur over the left paravertebral interscapular area is associated with coarctation of the aorta. Signs and symptoms include hypertension in upper extremities and weak, delayed pulses in the lower extremities.
❌ Continuous murmur at the left infraclavicular area:
Incorrect: A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) occurs when the ductus arteriosus fails to involute after birth, resulting in a left to right shunt. Infants may present with signs of heart failure, failure to thrive, poor feeding, and respiratory distress; adults may have features of Eisenmenger syndrome, such as cyanosis and clubbing. A PDA is characterized as a “machine-like murmur” best heard over the left infraclavicular area.
❌ Systolic ejection murmur over the 3rd right intercostal space:
Incorrect: A systolic ejection murmur over the 3rd right intercostal space is associated with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). Patients with HOCM are usually young and may present with dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, atypical or anginal chest pain, exertional syncope, palpitations, and sudden cardiac death.
✅ Diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Holosystolic murmur over the left sternal border:
Incorrect: A holosystolic murmur heard over the 4th left intercostal space (tricuspid area) suggests tricuspid regurgitation or a ventricular septal defect. Tricuspid regurgitation presents with right-sided heart failure (HF), hepatic congestion, ascites, and peripheral edema.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of progressive lethargy, shortness of breath, and abdominal pain for three days. The shortness of breath began suddenly while watching TV. His medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, obesity, and a thirty pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.76° F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 130/60 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distention, right upper quadrant tenderness, and +2 peripheral edema. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The left calf is swollen and tender to palpation when compared to the right calf. Which of the following findings is most likely to be found on cardiac auscultation?

choices.text: Systolic ejection murmur over the right sternal border
Holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border radiating to the axilla
Opening snap followed by a diastolic murmur over the left lower sternal border
Continuous murmur over the left infraclavicular area
Holosystolic murmur over the 4th left intercostal space

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, tachycardia, and signs of right heart failure and deep vein thrombosis. These findings suggest tricuspid regurgitation (TR) secondary to pulmonary embolism. Tricuspid regurgitation can be heard over the 4th left intercostal space (tricuspid area) as a holosystolic murmur.

TR can be primary or secondary, with primary TR as the less common form. Primary conditions include diseases that directly damage the valve such as infective endocarditis, rheumatic heart disease, or carcinoid syndrome. Secondary TR (functional) is defined as regurgitation with normal valve leaflets, and it usually occurs in the setting of right atrial and ventricular dilation. Secondary causes include conditions that induce pulmonary hypertension, which result in right ventricle dilation and ultimately right-sided heart failure. Examples include mitral stenosis or regurgitation, left to right shunt (e.g. ASD), Eisenmenger syndrome, pulmonary artery or valve stenosis, as well as primary pulmonary disease (cor pulmonale, pulmonary embolism, and pulmonary hypertension of any cause).

Option Analysis

❌ Systolic ejection murmur over the right sternal border:
Incorrect: The murmur of aortic stenosis (AS) is characterized as a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur over the right 2nd intercostal space with radiation to the carotids. AS is the most common cause of left ventricular outflow obstruction, and it is commonly associated with age-related calcification of the aortic valve.  Clinical findings of AS include exertional dyspnea, decreased exercise tolerance, dizziness, and syncope. This patient presents with signs of acute right heart failure and deep vein thrombosis, suggesting tricuspid regurgitation.
❌ Holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border radiating to the axilla:
Incorrect: Mitral regurgitation may be primary, due to mitral valve prolapse, or secondary  to other causes such as ischemia, left ventricular dilation (functional MR), infective endocarditis, or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Common findings of MR include exertional dyspnea, fatigue, and pulmonary edema. This patient’s pulmonary examination is unremarkable.
❌ Opening snap followed by a diastolic murmur over the left lower sternal border:
Incorrect: Mitral stenosis (MS) is heard as an opening snap followed by a rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur that is best heard at the 5th left midclavicular intercostal space (mitral area). Clinical features of MS include dyspnea, chest pain, hemoptysis, atrial fibrillation, pulmonary hypertension, and hoarseness secondary to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve with from atrial enlargement.
❌ Continuous murmur over the left infraclavicular area:
Incorrect: A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) occurs when the ductus arteriosus fails to involute after birth, resulting in a left to right shunt. Infants may present with signs of heart failure, failure to thrive, poor feeding, and respiratory distress; adults may have features of Eisenmenger syndrome, such as cyanosis and clubbing. A PDA is characterized as a “machine-like murmur” best heard over the left infraclavicular area.
✅ Holosystolic murmur over the 4th left intercostal space:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of dyspnea, dizziness, and associated chest pain. He became more concerned when he was walking up stairs and suddenly “passed out.” His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin. He smoked one pack per day for forty years but does not use excessive alcohol or illicit drugs. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 139/75 mmHg. On physical examination, a systolic murmur is appreciated over the right sternal border, which decreases with sustained hand grip. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with classic features of symptomatic aortic stenosis (AS), including dyspnea, decreased exercise tolerance, dizziness, syncope and a systolic murmur over the right sternal border. The most common cause of aortic stenosis in adults over the age of 60 is age-related calcification.

Common clinical findings of AS include exertional dyspnea, decreased exercise tolerance, dizziness, syncope, exertional angina, and arrhythmias. During exertion, left ventricular dysfunction ensues as the heart pumps against a stenotic valve--thus limiting ejection fraction and blood flow to both peripheral tissues and coronary arteries. On physical examination, AS is heard as a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur over the right 2nd right intercostal space. Additional physical findings include a  soft S2, an ejection click, and a weak carotid pulse with a delayed peak (“Pulsus parvus et tardus”).






The most common cause of aortic stenosis (AS) in individuals above the age of 60 is age-related calcification. In patients under the age of 60, AS is associated with a bicuspid aortic valve or rheumatic heart disease. Clinical manifestations include signs of left ventricular outflow obstruction, such as exertional dyspnea, dizziness, syncope, and angina. AS leads to a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur over the right sternal border. 

Option Analysis

❌ Bicuspid aortic valve:
Incorrect: Bicuspid aortic valve is associated with early-onset calcification in patients under the age of sixty. This patient’s constellation of findings is suggestive of more dangerous cardiac pathology.
❌ Untreated group A streptococcus infection:
Incorrect: Untreated group A strep infection is most commonly associated with mitral regurgitation--less so aortic or tricuspid regurgitation. Aortic regurgitation, if present, is almost always seen concurrently with mitral insufficiency. This patient’s findings are consistent with isolated aortic stenosis.
❌ Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease :
Incorrect: Pulmonary arterial hypertension may occur as a result of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; however, it usually presents with signs of right-sided heart failure, such as dyspnea, hepatic congestion, and peripheral edema.
✅ Age-related valve calcification:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Myxomatous valve degeneration:
Incorrect: Myxomatous valve degeneration is a cause of primary mitral valve prolapse and is characterized by non-inflammatory abnormal tissue deposition (glycosaminoglycan) around cardiac valves. Mitral valve prolapse presents with a late-systolic, crescendo murmur and a midsystolic click appreciated over the cardiac apex.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to shortness of breath on exertion and occasional chest pain. Her medical history is significant for a “heart sound” that was diagnosed as a child after having a prolonged illness. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. She immigrated from Peru two years ago with her family. Her temperature is 36.4°C (97.5° F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 130/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pulsations of the nail bed. Cardiac examination shows an abnormal heart sound over the left sternal border on auscultation (see image below). Which of the following maneuvers will likely decrease the intensity of this heart sound?
questions.solution:
This woman recently immigrated from Peru, where she was diagnosed with a “heart sound” after a prolonged illness. She is now presenting with some of the classic signs of aortic regurgitation (AR), which is most likely due to untreated rheumatic fever. In developed countries, AR is most often due to congenital bicuspid aortic valve, aortic root dilation, and endocarditis. Symptoms of AR include exertional dyspnea, angina, and palpitations, and the condition can eventually lead to left heart failure.

Aortic insufficiency leads to blood return to the left ventricle during diastole and an increase in the end diastolic volume. In an attempt to compensate for the increase in wall stress, the left ventricle undergoes eccentric hypertrophy, leading to an increased stroke volume. This increased stroke volume increases the systolic pressure, while the regurgitation leads to a rapid fall in diastolic pressure and collapse of the arteries -- which, in combination, results in a wide pulse pressure (systolic pressure minus diastolic blood pressure). The resulting wide pulse pressure is responsible for a number of characteristic physical findings including: head bobbing (de Musset sign), capillary pulsations of the fingertips or lips, and abrupt distention and collapse of the arterial pulse (water hammer sign). In addition, patients may describe palpitations from forceful contractions of the heart.

On auscultation, a high-pitched “blowing” early diastolic decrescendo murmur is expected at the left sternal border. Anything that decreases venous return to the heart, and therefore the preload, will cause a decrease in the intensity of the AR murmur. This includes abrupt standing and valsalva.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Passive leg raising:
Incorrect: Passive leg raising leads to an increase in venous return, which causes the aortic regurgitation murmur to intensify (also MR & VSD). In contrast, the murmur of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy becomes softer, and the murmur of mitral valve prolapse shortens.
❌ Sustained hand grip:
Incorrect: Sustained hand grip leads to constriction of the arteries of the hand, causing an increase in afterload and backflow pressure. This maneuver will cause murmur intensity to increase, not decrease.
✅ Abrupt standing:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Rapid squatting:
Incorrect: Rapid squatting leads to an increase in venous return, increase in preload, and increased afterload. Squatting causes the aortic regurgitation murmur to intensify. In general, most murmurs intensify with squatting with the exception of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, which softens, and the murmur onset in mitral valve prolapse is delayed.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to his primary pediatrician's office for evaluation of sore throat and fever for 3 days. He has received all childhood vaccinations. His medical history is unremarkable. He and his family immigrated from Vietnam 2 years ago. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. Examination of the patient’s throat is shown below. This patient is at risk for developing which of the following clinical manifestations?

 
Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Myocarditis, membranous pharyngitis, and anterior neck lymphadenopathy

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a sore throat, fever, and tonsillar exudate, a classic presentation of group A streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) pharyngitis, which is associated with acute rheumatic fever (ARF).

Acute rheumatic fever is an early sequelae that occurs approximately 2 weeks following group A Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis. Clinical manifestations include arthritis, carditis, chorea, erythema marginatum, and subcutaneous nodules. The heart involvement associated with ARF is typically pancarditis, involving the pericardium, epicardium, myocardium, and endocardium (valvulitis). The damage to the valves may become chronic and progressive, leading to mitral (most common), aortic and rarely, tricuspid valves damage. Rheumatic heart disease may manifest acutely or years after the initial illness. Regurgitation is the most common finding but may progress to stenosis. Diagnosis is made via the Jones criteria (shown below). Prevention of ARF involves early diagnosis and antibiotic treatment of GAS infection.



Option Analysis

❌ Myocarditis, mucositis, and conjunctivitis:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Kawasaki disease. Other findings include fever, typically above 38.5ºC (101.3ºF), extremity edema, lymphadenopathy, arthritis, polymorphous rash, pericardial effusion, and coronary artery aneurysm. Kawasaki disease develops during the acute illness, unlike rheumatic fever with group A strep infection.
❌ Encephalopathy and myoclonic jerks:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with subacute sclerosing panencephalitis--a known sequelae of measles infection. This childhood viral infection is characterized by prodromal fever accompanied by cough, coryza, conjunctivitis and buccal lesions (Koplik spots). Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis occurs years after the primary infection. This child received all childhood vaccinations, including measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine.
✅ Carditis, arthritis, and subcutaneous nodules:
Correct: See main explanation.
❌ Parotitis and orchitis:
Incorrect: Mumps is a viral infection marked by prodromal fever, headache, myalgias, fatigue, anorexia, and parotid gland swelling. Complications include orchitis, meningitis, and deafness. This child received all childhood vaccinations, including measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine.
❌ Myocarditis, membranous pharyngitis, and anterior neck lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Diphtheria is an infectious condition caused by the gram-positive bacillus Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Initial symptoms include sore throat, malaise, anterior cervical lymphadenopathy (“bulls neck”), and low-grade fevers. The prototypical sore throat manifestation includes gray and white exudate, so-called pseudomembranes. Associated complications include myocarditis, CNS disturbance, and renal disease. This child received all childhood vaccinations, including the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is being evaluated in the cardiac telemetry unit for sudden onset dyspnea. Three days prior, she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention, which demonstrated right coronary artery stenosis. The ECG at that time demonstrated ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Current temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg. On physical examination, the following murmur pattern is appreciated over the 5th left midclavicular intercostal space. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s new onset dyspnea?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a new holosystolic murmur, hypotension, and dyspnea three days following an inferior wall MI, favoring the diagnosis of acute mitral regurgitation secondary to papillary muscle rupture.

Risk factors for acute mitral regurgitation include both STEMI and NSTEMI (especially of the inferior wall), left ventricular dilatation, mitral valve prolapse, infective endocarditis, blunt chest trauma, and chronic or acute rheumatic heart disease. In the case of inferior wall myocardial infarction, rupture of the posteromedial papillary muscle is by far more common than rupture of the anterolateral papillary muscle. The posteromedial papillary muscle is supplied by the posterior descending artery (most commonly a branch of the right coronary artery), whereas the anterolateral papillary muscle receives dual supply from both the left anterior descending and left circumflex arteries.

Clinical manifestations of acute papillary muscle rupture include hypotension, acute pulmonary edema, and a new onset holosystolic murmur best heard over the 5th left midclavicular intercostal space (cardiac apex). Diagnosis is confirmed via echocardiography, and treatment involves administration of afterload reduction agents (e.g. nitroprusside), vasopressors, and emergent surgery.

Option Analysis

✅ Papillary muscle rupture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ventricular septal rupture:
Incorrect: Ventricular septal rupture usually occurs in the first 24 hours following infarction. Risk is augmented with left anterior descending artery occlusion or extensive myocardial damage. Patients may present with a variety of symptoms ranging from exertional dyspnea to cardiogenic shock. A new holosystolic murmur is also appreciated, but it is typically at the right lower sternal border.
❌ Left ventricular free wall rupture:
Incorrect: Left ventricular free wall typically occurs within the first five days following myocardial infarction. Complete rupture results in hemopericardium and pericardial tamponade. Clinical findings of tamponade include muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and distended neck veins.
❌ Ventricular arrhythmia:
Incorrect: During the first 24 hours post-myocardial infarction, the most common cause of death is ventricular tachycardia/ventricular fibrillation and sudden cardiac death (SCD). However, a ventricular arrhythmia would not precipitate a holosystolic murmur.
❌ Ventricular aneurysm:
Incorrect: A true ventricular aneurysm typically develops anywhere from weeks to months following an anterior myocardial infarction. A true aneurysm is defined as an akinetic, fibrotic, and scarred myocardium. An acute-onset holosystolic murmur would be atypical.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of fatigue, chills, and anorexia for one week. The patient is undomiciled and has a history of intravenous heroin use. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 132/87 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears disheveled and has multiple track marks noted on the upper extremities bilaterally. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiovascular examination reveals a systolic murmur that increases in intensity with inspiration. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a new systolic murmur that increases in intensity with inspiration--suggestive of tricuspid regurgitation (TR) due to infective endocarditis. Tricuspid valve endocarditis is associated with IV drug use, and it is most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus. Other causes of TR include pulmonary hypertension, rheumatic heart disease, congenital anomalies, carcinoid syndrome, and ischemic heart disease.

TR refers to insufficient closure of the tricuspid valve during ventricular systole, resulting in backflow of blood into the right atrium. As a compensatory mechanism, the right ventricle undergoes eccentric hypertrophy and dilation in an attempt to improve right ventricular ejection fraction, which only worsens the regurgitation as the right heart fails. Regurgitant volume backs up into the venous system, resulting in jugular venous distention, hepatosplenomegaly (hepatic congestion), ascites and lower extremity edema. The characteristic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation is holosystolic and best heard over the 4th left intercostal space (tricuspid area). During inspiration, negative pressure increases the preload to the heart and increases the intensity of the murmur--a phenomenon known as the Carvallo sign.



Option Analysis

❌ Head bobbing:
Incorrect: Head bobbing (de Musset sign) can be observed in patients with aortic regurgitation. This patient's clinical history is more indicative of tricuspid regurgitation.
✅ Jugular venous distension:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hoarseness:
Incorrect: Hoarseness is associated with mitral stenosis, due to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve from left atrial enlargement. This patient has a systolic murmur.
❌ Syncope:
Incorrect: While not a specific sign, syncope is often associated with aortic stenosis, due to left ventricular outflow obstruction. Aortic stenosis is more often seen in older patients due to age-related calcification of the aortic valve.
❌ Brachial-femoral pulse delay:
Incorrect: Brachial-femoral pulse delay refers to hypertension in upper extremities and  weak, delayed pulses in lower extremities--a finding often seen in patients with coarctation of the aorta.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to his primary care physician’s office for evaluation of a skin rash and fatigue. He is in good health and achieved all childhood milestones. He did not receive any of the childhood vaccines per parental request. A few weeks ago he had a sore throat and fever that resolved without treatment. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the posterior pharynx is without erythema or exudate. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A blowing, holosystolic murmur is heard over the left sternal border. Examination of the skin demonstrates an erythematous rash over the torso and limbs. Which of the following best describes the mechanism underlying this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Vegetation formation over the tricuspid valve
Cross-Reactivity between a bacterial virulence factor and myosin
Endothelial damage to the vasa vasorum
Inhibition of protein synthesis via ADP-ribosylation

questions.solution:
This previously healthy boy presents with a new holosystolic murmur and a rash consistent with  erythema marginatum following an untreated group A strep infection, favoring the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever.

Acute rheumatic fever is an early sequelae that occurs approximately two weeks following group A Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis. Clinical manifestations include arthritis, carditis, chorea, erythema marginatum, and subcutaneous nodules.

Cardiac involvement associated with ARF is typically pancarditis, meaning inflammation of all layers of the heart (pericardium, epicardium, myocardium, and endocardium). The damage to the valves may become chronic and progressive, leading to mitral (most common), aortic and, rarely, tricuspid valve regurgitation. Rheumatic heart disease may manifest acutely or years following the initial illness. The pathogenesis involves antibody production and subsequent T cell response to myosin, which shares similar epitopes with the M protein virulence factor of GAS--thus resulting in a type II hypersensitivity reaction. This phenomenon is also known as molecular mimicry. Prevention of ARF involves early diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment of primary GAS infection.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Vegetation formation over the tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the pathogenesis of bacterial endocarditis--wherein a platelet-fibrin nidus forms and serves as a medium for bacterial colonization. Staphylococcus aureus is a highly virulent organism capable of damaging previously healthy valves. Bacterial endocarditis due to Staphylococcus aureus is more commonly seen in individuals who use intravenous drugs.
✅ Cross-Reactivity between a bacterial virulence factor and myosin:
Correct: See main explanation.
❌ Endothelial damage to the vasa vasorum:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the pathogenesis of cardiac tertiary syphilis. In this condition, Treponema pallidum damages the vasa vasorum that supplies blood to the aorta--resulting in aortic root dilation and regurgitation.
❌ Inhibition of protein synthesis via ADP-ribosylation:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the pathogenesis of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, which   inhibits protein synthesis via ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor E (EF-2). The presence of rash and new heart murmur favors the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever. Clinical findings of Corynebacterium diphtheriae include sore throat, malaise, anterior cervical lymphadenopathy (“bulls neck”), and low-grade fever.
❌ Actin polymerization:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the pathogenesis of Listeria monocytogenes, a gram-positive, facultative intracellular rod capable of transferring between cells via actin polymerization and evading immune response. Clinical manifestations include gastroenteritis, chorioamnionitis, septicemia, spontaneous abortion, and meningitis in the elderly, immunocompromised and neonates.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of progressive fatigue and dyspnea for several months. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Family history is unremarkable. He traveled to South America one year ago but does not recall any subsequent illnesses. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 131/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears visibly dyspneic. A systolic murmur is auscultated over the cardiac apex. Pulmonary auscultation reveals diffuse rales over both lung fields. The patient undergoes cardiac biopsy, with the findings demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's clinical condition?


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This previously healthy patient presents with features of left heart failure and mitral regurgitation (systolic murmur over the apex). Cardiac biopsy demonstrates an Aschoff body (giant cell granuloma) and Anitschkow cells (macrophages with a wavy nucleus), favoring the diagnosis of rheumatic heart disease.

Acute rheumatic fever is an early sequela of untreated group A streptococcal throat infection that usually occurs two weeks following untreated group A Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis. Clinical manifestations include arthritis, carditis, chorea, erythema marginatum, and subcutaneous nodules. Cardiac involvement typically involves all layers of the heart (pancarditis).

Damage to cardiac valves often becomes chronic and progressive, leading to mitral (most common), aortic, and, rarely, tricuspid valve damage. Rheumatic heart disease may manifest years after the initial episode of GAS pharyngitis. Regurgitation is the most common complication, but it may progress to stenosis. Pathogenesis involves antibody production and subsequent T cell response against myosin that shares similar epitopes with the M protein virulence factor of the bacteria (type II hypersensitivity).    

Option Analysis

❌ Parasitic infection:
Incorrect: Chagas disease is caused by the protozoa Trypanosoma cruzi, which is transmitted to humans via the triatomine insect (kissing bug). Clinical manifestations include dilated cardiomyopathy, megacolon, and megaesophagus. Chagas disease leads to biventricular dysfunction with predominant right-sided heart failure (e.g., elevated JVP, peripheral edema) rather than left-sided (e.g., dyspnea and pulmonary crackles). This patient’s biopsy results favor a different diagnosis.
✅ Bacterial infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Viral infection:
Incorrect: Viral myocarditis should be suspected in patients who present with new unexplained cardiac symptoms and a recent upper respiratory tract infection (up to 3 months following the initial insult). Clinical presentation varies, ranging from asymptomatic to fatigue, chest pain, heart failure, arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or sudden death. Viral myocarditis could explain the patient’s symptoms; however, the biopsy results favor another diagnosis.
❌ Autoimmune granulomatous disease:
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis is an autoimmune condition marked by a noncaseating granulomatous disease. Clinical manifestations include restrictive lung physiology, erythema nodosum, and arthropathy. Cardiac involvement may include heart failure, valvular dysfunction, conduction abnormalities, and pericardial effusion. Biopsy demonstrates noncaseating granulomas and contains both Schaumann and asteroid bodies.

questions.text: A study is done to determine the pathophysiology of acute rheumatic fever after Streptococcus pyogenes infection. It was shown that antibodies against a protein from the bacteria could give rise to acute rheumatic fever due to molecular mimicry between this protein and human antigens. Which of the following best describes the function of this bacterial protein?

choices.text: It breaks down hyaluronic acid in the skin
It is responsible for the hemolysis of red blood cells
It is responsible for toxic shock syndrome
It helps invasion of the tissues
It inhibits phagocytosis of the bacteria

questions.solution:
Streptococcus pyogenes, known as group A strep (GAS), is a Gram-positive catalase-negative coccus that forms chains and pairs. It causes skin infections (e.g., impetigo, erysipelas, cellulitis) and pharyngitis. GAS also causes many diseases due to its toxins and sequelae of immunological reactions to the bacteria and its toxins (e.g., rheumatic fever, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis).

GAS is an encapsulated bacterium, and the capsule helps in evading phagocytosis. In addition, a structural protein found on the capsule of GAS called M protein helps prevent phagocytosis by binding to complement regulators and fibrinogen. M protein also helps in the attachment of the bacteria to host cells. Antibodies against M protein help in defense against the bacteria. These antibodies are implicated in the pathogenesis of acute rheumatic fever because the M protein structurally resembles specific structures in the human body, specifically myosin and glycogen in the heart and smooth muscles. This autoimmune attack of the antibodies against M protein on the heart and human tissues leads to rheumatic fever. This process is known as molecular mimicry.  


GAS also produces several exotoxins which help destroy tissue and allow GAS to invade – hyaluronidase, streptokinase, and streptolysin O and  S. Streptolysin O and S also mediate hemolysis of red blood cells.
 

The erythrogenic toxins (also known as streptococcal pyrogenic toxins) are responsible for the rash in scarlet fever and mediating toxic shock syndrome by acting as superantigens.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ It breaks down hyaluronic acid in the skin:
Incorrect: Hyaluronidase is an exotoxin produced by group A strep. It breaks down hyaluronic acid, helping the bacteria invade human tissue.  
❌ It is responsible for the hemolysis of red blood cells:
Incorrect: Streptolysin O and S are exotoxins that are responsible for causing the hemolysis of red blood cells.  
❌ It is responsible for toxic shock syndrome  :
Incorrect: Toxic shock syndrome (or toxic shock-like syndrome) is due to erythrogenic toxins, not M protein.  
❌ It helps invasion of the tissues  :
Incorrect: M protein does not help in the invasion of the tissues. Exotoxins produced by group A strep that helps in tissue invasion include hyaluronidase, streptokinase, and streptolysin.  
✅ It inhibits phagocytosis of the bacteria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
